After four-and-a-half years, a federal judge has ruled the Gloucester County School Board's bathroom policy discriminated against our client Gavin Grimm.
 ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌  ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌ ‌

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

A federal judge has ruled in our client Gavin Grimm's favor in his sex discrimination lawsuit against the Gloucester County School Board!

Gavin has been fighting for four and a half years to get a policy at his former high school changed so transgender students won't be forced to use restroom facilities that are inconsistent with their gender identity.

In her ruling, Judge Arenda L. Wright Allen in the U.S. District Court for the Eastern District of Virginia declared the school board's policy discriminated against Gavin from the day it was enacted after parents complained about Gavin, now a 20-year-old trans man, using the boys' restroom while a student at Gloucester High School.

The judge also ordered the school board to correct Gavin's high school transcript to reflect that he is male. The school board has announced it plans to appeal the decision, but this ruling is a huge victory in the fight for trans students' rights.

"It is such a relief to achieve this closure and vindication from the court after four years of fighting not just for myself but for trans youth across America," said Gavin. "I promise to continue to advocate for as long as it takes for everyone to be able to live their authentic lives freely, in public, and without harassment and discrimination."

Other "must-knows" for August:

  • Sterling Glen update: Our housing discrimination lawsuit against Sterling Glen Apartments in Chesterfield County and its management has been settled. The defendants agreed to change their criminal background screening policy so it no longer is a blanket ban on all felonies and many misdemeanors, amounting to a modern-day redlining against African-Americans.
  • Save the date: The ACLU of Virginia's 50th Anniversary Celebration will be September 7 in Richmond, featuring civil rights activist Shaun King. RSVP today — seating is almost gone.

Thank you for sticking with us,

ACLU of Virginia
